title: 115_hr2650
content: The Act is titled the "Protecting Older Workers Against Discrimination Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings and purposes section. Congress reaffirmed the difficulty in detecting and proving unlawful discrimination in the Civil Rights Act of 1991. The Act approved "mixed motive" claims, where a protected characteristic was a motivating factor for any employment practice. Amendments were made to other civil rights statutes, including the Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967. In 2009, the Supreme Court ruled in Gross v. FBL Financial Services, Inc. that mixed motive claims were not available under the ADEA, shifting the burden of proof to the complainant to show that a protected characteristic was the "but for" cause of an unlawful employment practice. This decision narrowed the scope of protections under statutes not amended in 1991 to address mixed motive claims. The Act aims to clarify that mixed motive claims are available under the ADEA and similar civil rights provisions, rejecting the Supreme Court's reasoning in the Gross decision. It also clarifies that complaining parties can rely on any admissible evidence. The Act allows complaining parties to use any admissible evidence to prove unlawful employment practices, without needing to show that the protected characteristic was the sole cause. SEC. 3. STANDARDS OF PROOF. The Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 prohibits impermissible consideration of age in employment practices. An unlawful practice is established when age or a protected activity was a motivating factor, even if other factors were also involved. Complaining parties can rely on any admissible evidence to prove an unlawful practice. The Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 prohibits age discrimination in employment practices. An unlawful practice can be established if age or a protected activity was a motivating factor, without the need to prove it was the sole cause. Amendments to the Act include changes to remedies for unlawful practices. The Age Discrimination in Employment Act prohibits age discrimination in employment practices. Amendments to the Act include changes to remedies for unlawful practices, such as granting declaratory relief, injunctive relief, attorney's fees, and costs for claims where age was a motivating factor. Damages or orders for reinstatement, hiring, promotion, or payment are not awarded in such cases. The Age Discrimination in Employment Act prohibits age discrimination in employment practices. Amendments to the Act include changes to remedies for unlawful practices, such as granting declaratory relief, injunctive relief, attorney's fees, and costs for claims where age was a motivating factor. Sections of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 are also amended to clarify prohibitions against impermissible consideration of race, color, religion, sex, or national origin in employment practices. The Civil Rights Act of 1964 prohibits unlawful employment practices based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin. Amendments to the Act address mixed motive cases and clarify protections for individuals with disabilities under the Americans With Disabilities Act of 1990. The term 'demonstrates' in the context of employment practices means meeting the burdens of production and persuasion. A discriminatory practice is established when disability or a protected activity was a motivating factor, even if other factors were also involved. The complaining party can rely on any admissible evidence to prove a discriminatory practice under the Act, without needing to show that disability was the sole cause. Certain antiretaliation claims under Section 503(c) are amended to specify remedies for such claims. Certain antiretaliation claims under Section 102(e)(1) with respect to title I are subject to Section 107(c) and may result in declaratory relief, injunctive relief, and attorney's fees. Damages or orders requiring action are not awarded if the respondent would have taken the same action without the impermissible motivating factor. The Rehabilitation Act of 1973 is amended to include standards of causation or methods of proof from the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. The amendment applies to all federal employees covered by the Act. SEC. 4. APPLICATION. This Act and its amendments apply to all pending claims after enactment.
